ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: A Difficult Task for NEAT?
ygData.msgSnippet: ... I agree with Ken that the representation of the cards is a major issue, but I m afraid I don t quite understand your explanation of how you re handling it.

> --- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> > Hi Mitchell, concentration does sound like a very
> > interesting problem for an ANN.  It is probably
> > quite difficult since it involves long term 
> > accurate and discrete memory.  But the input
> > representaiton,
> > i.e. how you represent the cards to the network,
> > is probably a major issue.  And it's not clear
> what
> > the right way would be, so it needs careful
> > consideration
> > since some representations are likely impossible
> for
> > an ANN to
> > deal with.  

--- Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...> wrote:
> About the inputs & outputs, I'm envsioning 2 input
> lines for every card position.  One would be binary
> to
> tell whether there is a card there or not.  The
> other
> would go through steps of 1/N to identify the card.
> Or I might use all binary with N+1 lines for each
> position.  So a deck of 6 cards of 3 kinds would
> have
> 24 binary input lines.

I agree with Ken that the representation of the cards
is a major issue, but I'm afraid I don't quite
understand your explanation of how you're handling it.
 In this case:

King/clubs     2/hearts     10/spades
10/spades      King/clubs   2/hearts

How many inputs does your NN have?  It sounds like 12
from your explanation...is that right?  So for the
first row/first column, you're going to have one
boolean input, either 0 or 1 depending on whether
there's a card there?  But what is the other input
going to be?  

If your inputs range from 0 to 1, are you representing
each type of card as a value range (e.g. King/clubs is
from 0 to 0.33, 2/hearts is from .33 to .66, etc.)?

I also think that Concentration sounds like an
interesting test domain, and I'm interested in how
card games are represented.  

Philip and I are still trying to get our NEAT
implementation off the ground.  Hopefully our design
will make it easier to plug new domains in, and we'll
have a chance to mess around with Concentration a
little.  But we're also avid Bridge players, and have
thought some about trying to apply neuroevolution to
it.  

In the case of Bridge, the cards are ranked in power
from 2 to Ace (though the relative power of a given
card is also contextual).  I'm thinking that it will
be necessary to represent each card with multiple
inputs, but I'm not really sure.

Derek
